This has been done. I have seen individuals (I might call by name, but forbear) who asked simple advantages. Seeing they would not help, they would not express their sympathy in the work, or cooperate, only so far as wages was concerned--in a poverty-stricken field, where the poor must be helped in order to help themselves.--Letter 221, 1899. (Written to Elder and Mrs. S. N. Haskell, August, 1899, from "Sunnyside," Cooranbong, N.S.W.) 

Ellen G. White Estate Washington, D. C. October 5, 1983
